final_answer.precision_note: Mass and % are 3 s.f.; maximum CO2 mass reported to 3 s.f.

method: First find the mass of CaCO3 in the impure limestone: m(CaCO3) = 5.00 g × 0.840 = 4.20 g. Calculate molar masses from the given atomic data: Mr(CaCO3) = 40.1 + 12.0 + 3×16.0 = 100.1; Mr(CO2) = 12.0 + 2×16.0 = 44.0. Convert CaCO3 mass to moles using n = m/Mr: n(CaCO3) = 4.20/100.1 = 0.04196 mol. From CaCO3 + 2HCl → CaCl2 + CO2 + H2O, the mole ratio CaCO3:CO2 is 1:1, so n(CO2) = 0.04196 mol. Convert moles of CO2 to mass: m(CO2) = n×Mr = 0.04196 × 44.0 = 1.846 g ≈ 1.85 g.
checks: Only 84.0% of 5.00 g reacts, so CO2 mass must be well below what 5.00 g pure CaCO3 would produce.
Stoichiometry is 1 mol CaCO3 to 1 mol CO2, matching the balanced equation.
